critique: This document designates INTELSAT as an international organization entitled to certain privileges, exemptions, and immunities under the International Organizations Immunities Act. It also extends certain privileges to representatives to the Board of Governors of INTELSAT. There is no clear indication of a left or right ideological tilt. The document does not directly address immigration. It could be argued that granting privileges to an international organization expands executive power, but the action is based on existing legislation. The document does not significantly impact federalism. It does not directly address national security or civil liberties. The document has a slight impact on economic regulation by granting exemptions to an international organization. The document does not directly address social inclusion.
